quoteLast: --Lieutenant Bronsfield was about to leave his watch to turn in when his attention was attracted by a distant and quite unexpected hissing sound.
title: The Moon-Voyage
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905

quoteLast: in the morning) Lieutenant Bronsfield was preparing to leave the watch and return to his cabin, when his attention was attracted by a distant hissing noise. His comrades and himself first thought that this hissing was caused by the letting off of steam; but lifting their heads, they found that the noise was produced in the highest regions of the air.
title: From the Earth to the Moon, Direct in Ninety-Seven Hours and Twenty Minutes: and a Trip Round It
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905; Hildibrand, Henri Théophile, 1824-1897 [Engraver]; Bayard, Émile Antoine, 1837-1891 [Illustrator]; Neuville, Alphonse Marie de, 1835-1885 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: ] About thirty-six minutes past twelve we reached one of the most difficult places--a succession of waves, with many rocks projecting out of the water, between which the boats, now in full career, and with rapid evolutions, glided successfully. The adventure was accomplished with equal skill by the two crews, who exerted their powers to the utmost. At
quoteLast: we arrived at [Dini portage.] Dini, the most considerable waterfall in the whole distance; and here we had to take the boats out of the water; and, availing ourselves of the lianas which hung down from the lofty forest trees like ropes, we dragged them over the rocks.
title: The Former Philippines Thru Foreign Eyes
author: Craig, Austin, 1872-1949 [Editor]; Comyn, Tomás de; Jagor, Fedor, 1816-1900; Virchow, Rudolf, 1821-1902; Wilkes, Charles, 1798-1877

quoteFirst: So half an hour passed and found me still waiting. It must have been nearly one o’clock by this time. I recollect that it was
quoteLast: precisely when our forward “look-out” discerned the lights of the Diamond Ship upon a far horizon, and Captain Larry burst in upon me with his splendid news. Now, surely, had I no further need of messages. You may judge how I followed him to the deck to feed my eyes upon the spectacle.
title: The Diamond Ship
author: Pemberton, Max, 1863-1950

quoteLast: in the morning) Lieutenant Bronsfield was preparing to leave the watch and return to his cabin, when his attention was attracted by a distant hissing noise. His comrades and himself first thought that this hissing was caused by the letting off of steam; but lifting their heads, they found that the noise was produced in the highest regions of the air.

author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905; Hildibrand, Henri Théophile, 1824-1897 [Engraver]; Bayard, Émile Antoine, 1837-1891 [Illustrator]; Neuville, Alphonse Marie de, 1835-1885 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: The race was won by S. C. 131 (Lieutenant Joseph L. Day), which arrived at Ambrose Channel lightship at
quoteLast: , August 19, 1919. Her running time was 56 hours, 56 minutes--8 hours and 43 minutes less than that made by the _Dream_, which had set the fastest pace in 1914. Four of the others also beat the best previous record.
title: Our Navy at war
author: Daniels, Josephus, 1862-1948
